title: Are extremely visual thinkers at a disadvantage in mathematics? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are some very visual fields in mathematics, for example geometry and trigonometry. Some abstract problems can be turned into visual problems with enough practice. For example, combinatorics is often about the positioning of objects or people. Therefore, it depends on what branch of mathematics you refer to. You mention statistics, some forms of statistics are very combinatoric in nature. My major has lots of statistics so I can verify that personally. The basic distributions are much easier to understand if you think about them visually. When first learned them, I thought it was just memorizing a bunch of formulas. Once I learned to think about them visually, the binomial, geometric, negative binomial, and hypergeometric distributions became SO MUCH easier to deal with. The way I visualize binomial is having x successes and n-x failures. You can picture successes and failures in your head however you want. I will use X for successes and O for failures. If n is 6 for example, you could have this: 1 success: just picture the arrangements where you would have 1 X with 5 Os It could be XOOOOO it could be OXOOOO it could be OOXOOO etc… THAT is what (nx)(nx) refers to. You rearranging the items as many ways as possible. Then the pxpx represents the probability of having that many Xs. The (1−p)n−x(1−p)n−x represents that all the rest are the complement. The way I visualize geometric is by having 1 success at the very end, and the rest are failures. If x is 6 for example, you could have this: OOOOOX If x is 4, you would have this OOOX The success is always at the end. That success is at probability p, all the rest is at probability 1-p. The way I visualize negative binomial is to realize the very last one HAS to be X. Then the other ones could be rearranged. So when you look at the probability that the 2nd success happens on the 6th attempt, you already know there are 6 terms, and the last term is success. Therefore you could have any of these: XOOOOX OXOOOX OOXOOX etc… The way I visualize hypergeometric is more complicated: Both the successes and failures could be rearranged. Therefore, you need to multiply the number of arrangements of successes (out of all the successes in the population) by the number of arrangements of failures (out of all the failures in the population). Then, to make it a probability you have to divide by the number of arrangements possible when it doesn’t matter if you are dealing with successes or failures. Since the geometric and exponential distributions are memoryless, sometimes conditional distributions can be simplified visually as well. The uniform distribution is possibly the most visual of all, it is just rectangles. Also, thinking about the normal distribution visually helps out a lot as well due to it’s symmetry. As far as pure math, I don’t have as much experience with that.

No. Every mathematician perceives math in his/her way. Jacob Barnett is a kid who is a math “genius”, and he is a visual thinker. Terry Tao is known to being one of the best mathematician alive, and he confessed that he does not really get Topology, but he translates it into Geometry (No, they are not the same thing). So you can find a way to translate the equations (or whatever) into visual ideas. Besides, there are so many math topics that are visual, so you can try to find a way to translate the abstract ones into visual and structured ones.

I think anything with geometry can be very visual, and visual thinkers can be at an advantage. However, I think that although subjects like abstract algebra and number theory can be visualized, they are more like learning a language: there is a set of symbols and notation that really have to be learned and manipulated in the way one learns (e.g.) French. This can always be translated into imagery, but it is hard… Also, at the higher levels, subjects like geometry involve a lot of terminology and notation as well, so if you can’t learn that very well, you are at a disadvantage. Nevertheless, maybe some of the best mathematicians are highly creative, and what is like learning linguistics to me, is just ‘mental imagery’ to them…

I think visual thinkers are in advantage in mathematics. This is because, in mathematics, you need to understand the concepts clearly prior to start solving the problems. In such cases, visual thinking might be a boon. For instance, while jumping into 3D geometry from plane geometry, visual thinkers will no doubt learn faster and much better than others. A visual thinker with adequate practice must be able to succeed in Mathematics.
